newsitem.title: FRANCE: Carlos the Jackal tight-lipped on start to career.
newsitem.headline: Carlos the Jackal tight-lipped on start to career.

text.p: Carlos the Jackal has refused to answer questions about the shooting which allegedly launched his guerrilla career, telling a French anti-terrorism judge he could not reveal the secrets of his "revolutionary organisation".

Justice sources said that Carlos, in a Paris jail since his arrest in Sudan two years ago, faced Judge Jean-Louis Bruguiere on Tuesday to be quizzed for the first time about the 1975 killing of two French secret service agents in Paris.
Investigators plan to put Carlos on trial next year for shooting dead the unarmed agents and their Lebanese informer, and wounding a third agent, at a Latin Quarter flat.
Carlos was sentenced in his absence in 1992 to life in jail for the killings.

"I belong to a revolutionary organisation and therefore I cannot tell you where I was at the time or tell you about events," a justice source quoted Carlos as repeatedly telling Bruguiere during a tense confrontation in the Palais de Justice.
The judge's questions focused on the whereabouts of the Venezuelan-born Carlos, whose real name is Illich Ramirez Sanchez, at the time of the June 1975 shooting.
"The judge's questions are getting longer and longer but Carlos won't talk. The judge can't stand Carlos any more," one source said.

The Paris-based Al-Watan magazine quoted Carlos as bragging about the killings in a 1979 interview. But Carlos has denied giving the interview since his arrest, saying it was planted by an unspecified Arab country's secret service.

Witnesses have testifed that Carlos shot dead the two DST counter-espionage agents and an accomplice he apparently believed had betrayed him when the officers called at a flat in Toullier Street to check his identity.
The shooting forced Carlos into the shadows for nearly two decades until he was seized by the DST itself in Sudan in August 1994.
Carlos disputes experts' reports that his fingerprints were found at the Paris flat and that the type of pistol used indicates he was the killer, justice sources said.
The sources said Carlos's lawyer had demanded that three Venezuelan eyewitnesses, who were students and in the flat at the time, be questioned again about the incident.

Bruguiere abruptly put an end to the questioning shortly after 6 p.m. (1700 GMT) when a colleague rushed in to tell him of the bombing of a train at a regional express station in Paris, the sources said.
The blast which bore the hallmarks of Algerian Moslem fundamentalists killed two people and injured 79 others.

French police accuse Carlos of killing 83 people in a series of attacks in Europe and the Middle East. The boldest incident with which he was linked was the kidnapping of 11 OPEC oil ministers in Vienna in 1975.

Carlos is also under investigation for a series of attacks including a 1983 railway station bombing in Marseille, which killed two people, a bombing against a high speed train the same day in which two died, and an explosion on a Paris-Toulouse train in 1982 which killed five people.
